awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Virus Assembly in Extreme Environments: A Structural and Genetic Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the structure of Sulfolobus spindle-shaped virus 1 (SSV1), a virus from volcanic hot springs.  The uniquely-shaped SSV1 thrives in acidic hot springs at above 175 ˚F (80 ˚C). Determining a high-resolution SSV1 structure will contribute to understanding how proteins interact at high temperatures. Discovering the genetic determinants of the SSV1 structure will provide insight into the stability not only SSV1, but all proteins. The research will also provide insight into virus evolution, and how life could have survived the extreme conditions present on early earth and/or on extra-terrestrial planets. The project will also provide research experiences to approximately 65 undergraduates working on SSV1 mutants.  The project will communicate science to the public in collaboration with the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry. 

This research will address three open questions regarding the structure of SSV1: How does the virus form its unique spindle-shaped structure? What is the structure of the SSV1 tail that binds to the host cell? What are the critical amino acids in the capsid proteins? To answer these questions, this research will use a combination of cutting-edge cryo-electron microscopy techniques and genetic screens and selections. The research will evaluate two competing models for the SSV1 structure and could provide a new structural paradigm for virus structure. This research will provide a strong foundation for community outreach to educate and excite the public, and inspire the next generation of researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For every branch and species of life, there is a virus that recognizes and infects it. Underlying the ubiquity of viruses is a compositional and structural simplicity. All viruses are essentially just a nucleic acid genome encapsidated in a protein container. Further, there are only a few different types of protein containers that viruses construct, and these containers are assembled from similalrly limited set of molecular building blocks, or 'protein folds'. Many of these protein folds are present in viruses that infect all domains of life, suggesting that these types of viruses might pre-date the last common universal ancestor.

The vast majority of known viruses infect eukaryotes and prokaryotes, and build either spherical or cylindirical containers to encase their genomes. Viruses that infect archaea, the third domain of life, are comparatively very poorly characterized. While there are archaeal viruses that resemble eukaryotic and prokaryotic viruses, there is also a vast array of archaeal virus morphologies that seem to be unique to this kingdom of life. One such virus family are the spindle-shaped fuselloviruses, or SSVs, which resemble large lemons with small tails on one end. Hence, understanding how these viruses assemble their unusual capsids will provide insight into the evolution of viruses in general, and suggest a new paradigm for virus self-assembly. In addition to their odd shapes, SSVs are remarkably stable, as they must be to infect their extremophile archaeal hosts, many of which live in springs of boiling acid. Because of their ability to thrive in these conditions archaeal viruses may also provide insight into how life can adapt to extreme environemnts, including those on extra-terrestrial planets. Finally, understanding the assembly of SSVs might inspire rationally designed nano-materials that can be used in harsh commerical chemical environments.

Using a combination of cryo-electron tomography (cryoET), cryo-electron microscopy (cryoEM), molecular biology, and virology, the goal of this project was to determine the structure of the model archaeal virus SSV1 and illuminate the pathway by which SSV particles self-assemble. We initially used cryoET to examine the overall morphology and inherent variabilty of SSV particles. Our results show that while there was considerable variability in the length and width of these lemon-shaped particles, many were similar in size and shape. Thus. we next used cryoEM single particle analysis to determine a nanometer-resolution structure of the most commonl particle. At this resolution, it was clear that these particles consisted of seven inter-twined spiral strands of the virus's major capsid protein. Each strand has a small radius at the ends of the particles and gradually increases to a maximum radius in the middle of the lemon-shaped particle. This result was reminiscent of the helical structures of rod-shaped cylindrical viruses, the major difference being that in rod shaped viruses the strands are helices rather than spirals, and thus have a constant radius. Hence SSV particles represent an intermediate between rod-shaped and shperical viruses; by using spiral rather than helical protein strands, a more-spherical lemon shape results. Further, the structure of the major capsid protein, the 'building block' of the virus, is similar to the structure of the major capsid proteins of some rod-shaped viruses, suggesting an evolutionary relationship between SSVs and rod-shaped viruses. In parallel to the structural work, we examined the effects of several mutations of the major capsid protein on particle assembly, and introduced cysteines at specific places in the protein sequence. These cysteines can be chemically modified with various chemical groups, providing a first step for the rational derivitization of SSV capsids.
